channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus News: Live Updates
item.description: Three children have died of a mysterious syndrome linked to the virus. President Trump’s support among seniors slips as the pandemic becomes more political.
item.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A care facility in Andover, N.J., last month.

item.title: The Coronavirus Is Widening the Class Divide in Education
item.description: Some private schools provide online luxury learning during the pandemic. As many public schools struggle to adjust, the nation’s educational gaps widen.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rachel Warach is a first-grade teacher at Chicago Jewish Day School, which provides its students with four hours and 15 minutes of daily live instruction, including yoga, art and music.

item.title: Mother's Day Bouquets: How Five Friends Saved a Tulip Farm From Covid-19
item.description: A group of old high school friends moved home and bought a tulip farm, just as the coronavirus threatened to devastate the industry. Here’s how the power of friendship and innovation saved them.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Johnson and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Fields of flowers at Tulip Town in Mt. Vernon, Wash., late last month.

item.title: Investigators Call Evidence in the Ahmaud Arbery Shooting ‘Extremely Upsetting’
item.description: A father and son were arrested in connection with the Feb. 23 killing of Mr. Arbery, which had led to protests and 2.23-mile runs to show support under the hashtag #IRunWithMaud.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Sarah Mervosh and Richard Fausset
item.media:description: A rally in Brunswick, Ga., on Friday to protest the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: For Michael Flynn, Dropped Charges Latest in Life Full of Reversals
item.description: For most of his life, Michael Flynn has swung from being “a good soldier” to committing radical disruptions.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department abruptly dropped charges against President Trump’s former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn.

item.title: For the First Time in Decades, This Recession Is a ‘Shecession’
item.description: A majority of the jobs lost in April were held by women, a sharp reversal of gains in the labor market.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:description: People waited in line for help with unemployment benefits at the One-Stop Career Center in Las Vegas in March.

item.title: Snow and Cold in May: A 'Nerve-Racking' Time for Growers
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic was already making life on the farm unpredictable, and then came an Arctic blast.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Maurice LeFranc, the owner of Touche-a-Tout Gardens in Pleasant Mount, Pa., covered young trees in his apple orchard to protect them from the cold weather on Saturday.

item.title: F.D.A. Approves First Antigen Test for Detecting the Coronavirus
item.description: The test offers medical workers and health authorities an inexpensive tool for fast, mass screening.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs

item.title: Andre Harrell, Executive Who Bridged Hip-Hop and R&B, Dies at 59
item.description: He founded the influential label Uptown Records and gave a first break to Sean Combs, who would go on to become one of hip-hop’s signature moguls.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:description: The music executive Andre Harrell in an undated photo. He helped build the careers of Mary J. Blige, Jodeci, Al B. Sure!, Guy and many others.

item.title: U.S. Hits Back at China With New Visa Restrictions on Journalists
item.description: The Trump administration is imposing 90-day limits on work visas for Chinese journalists, raising the threat of further retaliation by the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The newsroom of Xinhua News Agency in New York City in 2011.

item.title: Sister Fights to Free Uighur Businessman Held in China After U.S. Trip
item.description: Ekpar Asat came to the United States for the State Department’s most prestigious program for foreign citizens. Chinese security officers detained him weeks after he returned home.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Asat disappeared within three weeks of returning to China.

item.title: Nightly Applause Is Nice, but Some Doctors Think Votes Would Be Nicer
item.description: “My day job is talking people into getting colonoscopies,” one doctor said. So how much harder could the campaign trail be?
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Amanda Lucier for The New York Times
item.media:description: The pandemic has given front-line physicians like Dr. Maxine Dexter a rare view of the life-or-death stakes of government decision-making.

item.title: The Grapelord of Napa Faces a Threat Worse Than Plague
item.description: For 50 years, Andy Beckstoffer drove up the price of wine. Did the strategy work too well?
item.dc:creator: Ben Ryder Howe
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andy Beckstoffer in Rutherford, Calif. Napa Valley has unquestionably the best American terroir, and within it, the choicest land has his name on a billboard next to it.

item.title: Fight Over Virus’s Death Toll Opens Grim New Front in Election Battle
item.description: Elements of the right have sought to bolster President Trump’s political standing by turning scientific questions into political issues.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg and Jim Rutenberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodies were moved into a refrigerated truck last month outside Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn.

item.title: Live Coronavirus World Updates
item.description: Gulf states’ reliance on vast numbers of foreign workers is being shaken. Europe braces for clashes over cutting emissions and reopening economies.
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partitions at dining-hall tables in Suwon, South Korea, are in keeping with recommendations from the country’s task force of economists, sociologists and infectious-disease experts.

item.title: 2 Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Family Dollar Guard in Flint, Mich.
item.description: The authorities said the two men had been sought since May 1 in the shooting death of a security guard at the store in Flint, Mich.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Mele
item.media:description: Ramonyea T. Bishop, 23, left, and Larry E. Teague, 44, face felony premeditated murder and firearms charges.

item.title: No Charges for Parents of 5-Year-Old Who Took to the Highway in an S.U.V.
item.description: The couple were at work and had no idea that their son had sneaked out while his teenage sister watched him, a prosecutor said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: An image from dash cam video of a trooper pulling over a 5-year-old.

item.title: Georgia Killing Puts Spotlight on a Police Force’s Troubled History
item.description: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski
item.media:description: A cross near the Georgia neighborhood where Ahmaud Arbery, a black man, was fatally shot in February after being chased by a white former police officer and his son.

item.title: A Drug Cocktail Hastens Recovery in Some Coronavirus Patients
item.description: A combination of three antiviral drugs, including interferon, seemed to speed recovery, researchers reported.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients with Covid-19 hospitalized in Argentina. In a new study, those receiving a triple-drug treatment in Hong Kong improved more quickly than those in a comparison group, researchers reported on Friday.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Video Was Leaked by a Lawyer Who Consulted With Suspects
item.description: The lawyer, Alan Tucker, declined to comment on his conversations with the suspects, citing attorney-client privilege. He later said he would not be representing them.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: Demonstrators holding signs Friday at a memorial for Ahmaud Arbery in Brunswick, Ga., near where he was shot and killed in February.

item.title: Chief Justice Roberts Rejects Request for Inquiry into D.C. Appeals Court Vacancy
item.description: The top circuit court judge had asked the complaint be transferred and investigated, but the chief justice’s office said it did not qualify.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: Judge Justin Walker is sworn in prior to testifying before a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on Walker's nomination to be a U.S. circuit judge for the District of Columbia Circuit on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday.

item.title: Two White House Coronavirus Cases Raise Question of if Anyone Is Really Safe
item.description: If it is so hard to maintain a healthy environment at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, then how can businesses across the country establish a safe space for their workers?
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Reporters listening to Larry Kudlow speak on Friday outside the White House.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The coronavirus is not going to simply vanish after restrictions are lifted — instead, it may come back in waves.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Dropping of Michael Flynn Case Heightens Fear of Justice Dept. Politicization
item.description: Across the country, rank-and-file prosecutors cringed at another extraordinary intervention by Attorney General William P. Barr.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr has consistently sided with President Trump on politically-tinged issues.

item.title: Overlooked No More: June Almeida, Scientist Who Identified the First Coronavirus
item.description: In 1966, she used a powerful electron microscope to capture an image of a mysterious pathogen — the first coronavirus known to cause human disease.
item.dc:creator: Denise Gellene
item.media:credit: Norman James/Toronto Star, via Getty Images
item.media:description: June Almeida in 1963 at the Ontario Cancer Institute in Toronto. In her day she gained a reputation for “extending the range of the electron microscope to new limits.”

item.title: Motoko Fujishiro Huthwaite, 92, Last of the ‘Monuments Women,’ Dies
item.description: An American who was sent to Japan after Pearl Harbor, she was one of 345 people from 14 countries who helped preserve cultural treasures.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye

item.title: In Michael Flynn Case, William Barr Again Takes Aim at Robert Mueller Inquiry
item.description: The Justice Department’s move was the latest example of the attorney general’s effort to chisel away at the special counsel investigation and emphasize an alternate narrative.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: The investigation by Robert S. Mueller III revealed a historic campaign by Russia to sabotage the 2016 presidential election.

item.title: Tesla Tells Workers It Will Reopen California Factory Despite County Order
item.description: The electric car company told employees to report to work Friday, but a county official said Tesla did not meet the requirements for resuming production.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: Tesla’s factory in Fremont, Calif., in March. It has been closed since March 23.

item.title: Ahmaud Arbery Shooting: A Timeline of the Case
item.description: A look at the major moments between Mr. Arbery’s killing in a Georgia suburb and the arrest of two suspects, both charged with murder.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Brunswick, Ga., on Friday to protest the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery.

item.title: Haphazard Rollout of Coronavirus Drug Frustrates Doctors
item.description: Remdesivir was shipped to small hospitals even as besieged medical centers were denied access.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:credit: Stan Grossfeld/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston in March. Though other major hospitals did not receive supplies of remdesivir, Mass General did — without asking. “We have no idea how this landed with us,” said one doctor.

item.title: California to Mail All Voters Ballots for November Election
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday made California the first state to alter its plans for the general election in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Jennifer Medina
item.media:description: A polling place in Los Angeles in March.

item.title: Michael Pack: Trump Pushes for Senate to Confirm Conservative to Run Voice of America
item.description: A key Senate committee has scheduled a vote on the long-stalled nomination of Michael Pack, an ally of Stephen K. Bannon, to run the agency in charge of the Voice of America. Employees are worried.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Voice of America studio in Washington. Voice of America is the largest American international broadcaster.
